required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Feasibility of Immediate Postpartum Long-acting Reversible Contraception Implementation
clinical_study.official_title: Immediate Postpartum LARC Implementation: Pilot Study at Michigan Medicine

collaborator.agency: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of this study is to test and disseminate tools that drive successful immediate postpartum Long-Acting Reversible Contraception (LARC) implementation. The long-term goal is to reduce unintended pregnancy soon after childbirth by increasing access to immediate postpartum LARC for women who desire it.

detailed_description.textblock: Based on previous work, the investigators have generated a toolkit to guide the integration of immediate postpartum LARC services into widespread clinical practice. In the proposed work, this toolkit will be used to initiate immediate postpartum LARC services in a single site with low baseline immediate postpartum LARC uptake (Michigan Medicine). The investigators will conduct a feasibility study using mixed methods to assess acceptability and appropriateness of toolkit items; patient experience of care; immediate postpartum LARC utilization rate; and prenatal contraceptive counseling rate.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Surveys will be collected from pregnant or postpartum women, during the 6-12 months after implementation of a new protocol for peripartum contraceptive care
primary_outcome.description: Patient online surveys about their experience of care during prenatal visits, hospital stay, or postpartum office visit

primary_outcome.time_frame: Surveys will be collected from pregnant or postpartum women, during the 6-12 months after implementation of a new protocol for peripartum contraceptive care
primary_outcome.description: Online survey assessing experience of care, acceptability and appropriateness of implementation tools

primary_outcome.time_frame: Surveys will be collected from pregnant or postpartum women, during the 6-12 months after implementation of a new protocol for peripartum contraceptive care
primary_outcome.description: Online survey assessing experience of care, acceptability and appropriateness of implementation tools

primary_outcome.measure: Acceptability of implementation process - study site maternity care providers
primary_outcome.time_frame: Surveys will be collected during the 6-12 months after implementation of a new protocol for peripartum contraceptive care
primary_outcome.description: Online survey assessing overall experience of care delivery, acceptability and appropriateness of implementation tools

primary_outcome.measure: Appropriateness of implementation process - study site maternity care providers
primary_outcome.time_frame: Surveys will be collected during the 6-12 months after implementation of a new protocol for peripartum contraceptive care
primary_outcome.description: Online survey assessing overall experience of care delivery, acceptability and appropriateness of implementation tools

secondary_outcome.measure: Acceptability of implementation toolkit items - patients
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Interviews will take place after the survey is completed, during the 6-18 months after implementation of a new protocol for peripartum contraceptive care
secondary_outcome.description: 30-minute follow-up in-person interview of subgroup of patients who completed surveys

secondary_outcome.measure: Appropriateness of implementation toolkit items - patients
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Interviews will take place after the survey is completed, during the 6-18 months after implementation of a new protocol for peripartum contraceptive care
secondary_outcome.description: 30-minute follow-up in-person interview of subgroup of patients who completed surveys

secondary_outcome.measure: Acceptability of implementation toolkit items - providers
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Interviews will take place after the survey is completed, during the 6-18 months after implementation of a new protocol for peripartum contraceptive care
secondary_outcome.description: 30-minute follow-up in-person interview of subgroup of providers who completed survey

secondary_outcome.measure: Appropriateness of implementation toolkit items - providers
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Interviews will take place after the survey is completed, during the 6-18 months after implementation of a new protocol for peripartum contraceptive care
secondary_outcome.description: 30-minute follow-up in-person interview of subgroup of providers who completed survey

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured monthly, up to 24 months after toolkit implementation
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of delivered patients with documentation of prenatal counseling about postpartum contraception

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured monthly, up to 24 months after toolkit implementation
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of delivered patients with documentation of preference for immediate postpartum LARC who receive a LARC device

arm_group.description: Enrolled patients will take online surveys following a prenatal or a postpartum visit.
All enrolled patients will take online surveys following a prenatal or a postpartum visit. A subset will be interviewed after the postpartum survey.
All enrolled providers will take online surveys at 6-12 months after program implementation, and a subset will be interviewed.

intervention.description: Post-implementation patients and providers will be assessed after the implementation toolkit has been used to improve service delivery at the study site.

study_pop.textblock: Study population includes women receiving prenatal care and maternity providers working at the study site. The patient populations includes approximately 5000 women annually. The provider population includes approximately 400 maternity providers.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Female (patients)
- Pregnant (patients)
- Receiving obstetrical care at Michigan Medicine (patients)
- L&D provider at Michigan Medicine (providers)
Exclusion Criteria:
- non-English speaking
- unable to provide informed consent
